moves.1. e4: I do the kings pawn opening.
moves.2. Nf3: Not sure what opening this is called, but I generally play it. Develops the knight, while attacking the e pawn.
moves.3. Bc4: Develops my LSB, and attacks the weak f7 square.
moves.3... Nd7: ...? Any idea's what the point of this move was?
moves.4... a6: Black needs to develop! My white bishop is already on the a2-g8 squares, and has no ideas of moving to b5. I think Nf6 would be good here.
moves.5... h6: Black is in desperate need for development. Again, I think Nf6 is best.
moves.6. dxe5: "When your development is superior to the opponents, attack!"
moves.7. Bxf7+: This move is actually a big deal, as you'll see in the next couple of moves.
moves.8. Nxe5+: Black can't take the knight with his own, because then I win his queen with ...Nxe5, Qxd8
moves.8... Ke8: This is wrong, but I'm not really sure what to advise black to do at this point...
moves.9. Qh5+: And now for the major point of this annotation! If black hadn't pressed his h pawn in the beginning and mearly developed,  he would have been able to press his g pawn, or defend in some other manner.
moves.10. Qf7+: The black king is in peril!
moves.11. Nc4+: Black resigns here, which is understandable. I hope this annotation has showed the importance of not pressing the h and a pawns in the opening!

gameName: Why NOT to move the h & a pawn's early
